quest_title: Assuming fully decomposed, the volume of \(CO_{2} \) released at STP on heating 9.85 \(\textit{g}\) of \(BaCO_{3} \) (Atomic mass of \(\textit{Ba}\) =137) will be
explanation_txt:
\(BaCO_{3} \to BaO+CO_{2} \uparrow \)

Molecular weight of \(BaCO_{3} =137+12+3\times 16\) =197

197 \(\textit{gm}\) produces 22.4 \(\textit{L}\) at S.T.P.

\({\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} \) 9.85 \(\textit{gm}\) produces \(\cfrac{22.4}{197} \times 9.85=1.12L\) at S.T.P.

quest_title: The sum of a G.P. with common ratio 3 is 364, and last term is 243, then the number of terms is:
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{ar^{n} -a}{r-1} =364\)

\(\Rightarrow \cfrac{ar^{n-1} .r-a}{r-1} =364 \dots (i) \)

\( \Rightarrow \cfrac{3\times 243-a}{2} =364 \)

\( \Rightarrow a=1 \)

Now, putting this in (i), n = 6.
question_plain_title: The sum of a G.P. with common ratio 3 is 364, and last term is 243, then the number of terms is:
explanation_plain_text: Now, putting this in (i), n = 6.

So, the answer is \[ 4 \Delta \]

quest_title: If a, b, c are the position vectors of three collinear points, then the existence of x, y, z is such that
ans1_txt: \( x \mathbf { a } + y \mathbf { b } + z \mathbf { c } = 0 , x + y + z \neq 0 \)
ans2_txt: \( x \mathbf { a } + y \mathbf { b } + z \mathbf { c } \neq 0 , x + y + z = 0 \)
ans3_txt: \( x \mathbf { a } + y \mathbf { b } + z \mathbf { c } \neq 0 , x + y + z \neq 0 \)
ans4_txt: \( x \mathbf { a } + y \mathbf { b } + z \mathbf { c } = 0 , x + y + z = 0 \)
explanation_txt:
With reference to he figure,

\( \vec{b} - \vec{a} \) and \( \vec{c} - \vec{b} \) are collinear.

So, \( \vec{b} - \vec{a} = k ( \vec{c} - \vec{b} \) \) where 'k' is a scalar

Simplifying,

\( \vec{a} + (-1-k) \vec{b} + k\vec{c} = 0 \)

Or,

\( x\vec{a} + (-x-kx) \vec{b} + kx \vec{c} = 0 \)

Since, \( (x\vec{a} + y\vec{b} + z\vec{c} = 0) \) should be true for linealrly dependent vectors for some scalars \(x,y,z\), we have,

\( y = -x-kx \\ z = kx \\ Hence, \hspace{1mm} x+y+z = 0 \)

and are collinear.

explanation_txt:
Let \[ \begin{align} I &= \int _{0}^{\pi /2}e^{x} \sin \, x\, \, dx \\ & = -[e^{x} \cos x]_{0}^{\pi /2} +\int _{0}^{\pi /2}e^{x} \cos x\, dx \\ & =-[e^{x} \cos x]_{0}^{\pi /2} +[e^{x} \sin x]_{0}^{\pi /2} -\int _{0}^{\pi /2}e^{x} \sin x\, dx \end{align} \]

\[{\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} 2I=[e^{x} (\sin x-\cos x)]_{0}^{\pi /2} =(e^{\pi /2} +1)\]

Hence \[ \int _{0}^{\pi /2}e^{x} \sin xdx=\cfrac{1}{2} (e^{\pi /2} +1) \].

quest_title: The area of the region bounded by the curve \(y=x|x|\), \(\textit{x}\)-axis and the ordinate \(\textit{x} = 1\) and \(\textit{x} = -1 \) is given by :
explanation_txt:
We have:

\[ x|x| = \left\{ \begin{matrix} x^2 & (x\ge 0) \\ -x^2 & (x<0) \end{matrix} \right. \]

So, the required area is:

\[ A = \int_{-1}^0 -x^2 dx + \int_{0}^1 x^2 dx \]

\[\Rightarrow A = 2 \times \cfrac{1^3}{3} = \cfrac{2}{3} \]

quest_title: If the magnitudes of vectors \(\vec{A}, \vec{B} \text{ and } \vec{C}\) are 12, 5 and 13 units respectively and \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{A}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{B}}=\overrightarrow{\mathrm{C}}\) then angle between \(\vec{A} \& \vec{B}\) is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{C}=\sqrt{\mathrm{A}^{2}+2 \mathrm{AB} \cos \theta+\mathrm{B}^{2}}} \\ {\text { Or, } 13=\sqrt{5^{2}+2 \times 5 \times 12 \times \cos \theta+12^{2}}} \\ {\text { Or, } 169=25+144+120 \cos \theta} \\ {\text { Or, } 169=169+120 \cos \theta} \\ {\text { Or, } \cos \theta=0=\cos \cfrac{\pi}{2}} \\ {\therefore \theta=\cfrac{\pi}{2}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: The displacement-time graph for two particles \(A\) and \(B\) are straight lines inclined at angles of \(30 ^ { \circ }\) and \(60 ^ { \circ }\) with the time axis. The ratio of velocities of \(V _ { A } : V _ { B }\) is
explanation_txt:
Velocity in displacement time graph is given by slope of the curve.

Therefore, \(\cfrac { v _ { A } } { v _ { B } } = \cfrac { \tan \theta _ { A } } { \tan \theta _ { B } } = \cfrac { \tan 30 ^ { \circ } } { \tan 60 ^ { \circ } } = \cfrac { 1 / \sqrt { 3 } } { \sqrt { 3 } } = \cfrac { 1 } { 3 }\)

quest_title: A hollow glass cube of side 10cm is filled by ice at 0\({}^{0}\)c is placed in container of 100\({}^{0}\)c. If the thickness of cube is 2mm and thermal conductivity is 0.002cal/s cm\({}^{o}\)c. The rate of ice melt is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{A}=\cfrac{6 l^{2}+6(l-2 t)^{2}}{2}=3\left\{10^{2}+9.6^{2}\right\}\)

\(=565.48 \mathrm{cm}^{2}\)
\(\cfrac{\mathrm{Q}}{\mathrm{t}}=\cfrac{K A d \theta}{d l}=\cfrac{m}{t} \mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{f}}\)
\(\therefore \cfrac{m}{t}=\cfrac{0.002 \times 565.48 \times 100}{80 \times 0.2}=7.1 \mathrm{g} / \mathrm{s}\)

quest_title: Diffraction and interference of light suggest
explanation_txt: In diffraction and interference, light from different sources superimpose to give alternate bright and dark fringes. Particles in superimposition cannot vanish out rather increase in intensity. Waves on the otherhand, are energies which can collapse when one wave with the energy to perfom work on one direction is superimposed with another with the energy to perform work on opposite direction. Thus, diffraction and interference suggests light act as a wave.
question_plain_title: Diffraction and interference of light suggest
explanation_plain_text: In diffraction and interference, light from different sources superimpose to give alternate bright and dark fringes. Particles in superimposition cannot vanish out rather increase in intensity. Waves on the otherhand, are energies which can collapse when one wave with the energy to perfom work on one direction is superimposed with another with the energy to perform work on opposite direction. Thus, diffraction and interference suggests light act as a wave.

quest_title: Light waves can be polarized as they are
explanation_txt: Transverse waves are those waves in which the medium vibrates at right angles to the direction of its propagation. Thus the medium which vibrates perpendicular to the wave can be confined to a plane. Thus, only transverse wave can be polarized.
question_plain_title: Light waves can be polarized as they are
explanation_plain_text: Transverse waves are those waves in which the medium vibrates at right angles to the direction of its propagation. Thus the medium which vibrates perpendicular to the wave can be confined to a plane. Thus, only transverse wave can be polarized.

explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{KE} &=\cfrac{\mathrm{hc}}{\lambda}-\phi \\ &=\cfrac{6.62 \times 10^{-34} \times 3 \times 10^{8}}{180 \times 10^{-9}}-2 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \\ &=7.8 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{J} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: What is used as a moderator in a nuclear reactor?
explanation_txt: Graphite is a crystalline form of Carbon arranged in hexagonal structure. The carbon nuclides in the graphite absorb the relatively high kinetic energy that most neutrons have when they are emitted from nuclear fission. Thus, graphite is used as a primary moderator for nuclear reactors.
question_plain_title: What is used as a moderator in a nuclear reactor?
explanation_plain_text: Graphite is a crystalline form of Carbon arranged in hexagonal structure. The carbon nuclides in the graphite absorb the relatively high kinetic energy that most neutrons have when they are emitted from nuclear fission. Thus, graphite is used as a primary moderator for nuclear reactors.

quest_title: Lux is equal to
explanation_txt:
Lux is the unit of illuminance which is defined as luminous flux per unit area.

The unit of luminous flux is lumen. Therefore, lux = lumen/m2.

quest_title: A diver in a swimming pool wants to signal his distress to a person lying on the edge of the pool by flashing his water proof flash light
ans1_txt: He must direct the beam vertically upwards
ans2_txt: He has to direct the beam horizontally
ans3_txt: He has to direct the beam at an angle to the vertical which is slightly less than the critical angle of incidence for total internal reflection
ans4_txt: He has to direct the beam at an angle to the vertical which is slightly more than the critical angle of incidence for the total internal reflection
explanation_txt: When incident angle is greater than critical angle, then total internal reflection takes place and will come back in same medium.
question_plain_title: A diver in a swimming pool wants to signal his distress to a person lying on the edge of the pool by flashing his water proof flash light
explanation_plain_text: When incident angle is greater than critical angle, then total internal reflection takes place and will come back in same medium.
ans1_plain_text: He must direct the beam vertically upwards
ans2_plain_text: He has to direct the beam horizontally
ans3_plain_text: He has to direct the beam at an angle to the vertical which is slightly less than the critical angle of incidence for total internal reflection
ans4_plain_text: He has to direct the beam at an angle to the vertical which is slightly more than the critical angle of incidence for the total internal reflection

explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} l_{478} &=l_{5}\{1+\alpha(478-278)\} \\ &=100\left(1+17 \times 10^{-6} \times 200\right) \\ &=100.34 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: 1kg ice at 0\({}^{0}\)c is mixed with 1kg of water at 80\({}^{0}\)c then the temperature of mixture will be
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array}{l}{\text { ice }} \\ {\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Q}_{1} &=1 \times 80 \times 4200 \\ &=3360000 \mathrm{J} \end{aligned}}\end{array}\)

\(\begin{array} \text{water} \\ {1 \times 4200 \times 80} \\ {=336000 \mathrm{J}}\end{array}\)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{Q}_{1}=\mathrm{Q}_{2}} \\ {\therefore \text { temp }=0^{0} \mathrm{c}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: There are two metallic spheres of same radii but one is solid and the other is hollow, then
ans1_txt: Solid sphere can be given more charge
ans2_txt: Hollow sphere can be given more charge
explanation_txt: In case of metallic sphere either solid or hollow, the charge will reside on the surface of the sphere. Since both spheres have same surface area, so they can hold equal maximum charge.
question_plain_title: There are two metallic spheres of same radii but one is solid and the other is hollow, then
explanation_plain_text: In case of metallic sphere either solid or hollow, the charge will reside on the surface of the sphere. Since both spheres have same surface area, so they can hold equal maximum charge.
ans1_plain_text: Solid sphere can be given more charge
ans2_plain_text: Hollow sphere can be given more charge

or, \(\mathrm{C}=43 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{F}=43 \mu \mathrm{F}\)

quest_title: Which of the following is the most suitable material for making permanent magnet is?
explanation_txt:
Magnets are made from ferromagnetic materials.

Steel retains a permanent magnetic field even after the current stops flowing in the coil but soft iron loses magnetism soon after the current stops flowing in the coil. So steel is used to make permanent magnets while soft iron is used in making electromagnets.
question_plain_title: Which of the following is the most suitable material for making permanent magnet is?
explanation_plain_text:
Magnets are made from ferromagnetic materials.

Steel retains a permanent magnetic field even after the current stops flowing in the coil but soft iron loses magnetism soon after the current stops flowing in the coil. So steel is used to make permanent magnets while soft iron is used in making electromagnets.

quest_title: Flux (in Weber) in a closed circuit of resistance 10 \(\Omega\) varies with time \(\text{t}\) (in second) according to equation \(\text{\(\phi\)}\) = 6\(\text{t}\)\({}^{2}\) -5\(\text{t}\) + 1. What is the magnitude of the induced current at \(\text{t}\) = 0.25 second?
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} E=&-\cfrac{d \phi}{d t}=-(12 t-5) \\ \text { At } t &=0.25 ; E=-[12 \times 0.25-5]=2 \text { volt } \\ i &=\cfrac{E}{R}=\cfrac{2}{10}=0.2 \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: Flux (in Weber) in a closed circuit of resistance 10 varies with time (in second) according to equation = 6 -5 + 1. What is the magnitude of the induced current at = 0.25 second?

quest_title: A bar magnet of magnetic moment 2.0 J/T lies aligned with the direction of uniform magnetic field of 0.25T. What is the amount of work required to turn the magnet so as to align its magnetic moment normal to the field direction?
explanation_txt:
We know that,

Work done = change in potential energy

\(W = \Delta V = (V_f - V_i) \)

Potential energy of bar magnet with its magnetic moment inclined at angle '\(\theta\)’ with magnetic field is

\(V = -MB \cos \theta \)

\(V_i = -MB \cos 0^ \circ = -MB \)

\(V_f = -MB \cos 90^ \circ = 0 \)

\( \therefore \, W = 0 - (-MB) = MB = 2 \times 0.25 = 0.5 J \)

quest_title:
In a chemical reaction  
 \(\mathrm{N}_{2}+3 \mathrm{H}_{2} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}\) 
 At equilibrium point
ans1_txt: Equal volumes of \(\text{N\(_{2}\)}\) and \(\text{H\(_{2}\)}\) are reacting
ans2_txt: Equal masses of \(\text{N\(_{2}\)}\) and \(\text{H\(_{2}\)}\) are reacting
ans4_txt: The same amount of ammonia is formed as is decomposed into nitrogen and hydrogen.
explanation_txt: At the point of dynamic equilibrium the rate of forward and backward reactions are equal. However, the reaction proceed in both directions.
question_plain_title: In a chemical reaction At equilibrium point
explanation_plain_text: At the point of dynamic equilibrium the rate of forward and backward reactions are equal. However, the reaction proceed in both directions.
ans1_plain_text: Equal volumes of and are reacting
ans2_plain_text: Equal masses of and are reacting
ans4_plain_text: The same amount of ammonia is formed as is decomposed into nitrogen and hydrogen.

quest_title: When 100ml of M HCl is mixed with 100 ml of N  NaOH, the pH of the resulting solution is
explanation_txt:
\(100\,\text{ml}\) of \(1\text{M HCl} = 100 \, \text{ml}\) of \(1\text{N HCl}\)

So, \(N_1V_1=0.1\)

\(100\,\text{ml}\) of \(1\text{N NaOH}\)

So, \(N_2V_2=0.1\)

Hence the acid and base neutralize each other. So, the resulting solution will be neutral, \(pH=7\)

quest_title: Which of the following has hightst bond order?
explanation_txt:
\(\text{Bond Order } = \cfrac{\text{No. of electrons in anti-bonding Molecular Orbitals - No. of electrons in bonding Molecular Orbitals}}{2}\)

For \(O_2 = \cfrac{10-6}{2} = 2\)

For \(O_2^+ = \cfrac{10-5}{2} = 2.5\)

For \(O_2^- = \cfrac{10-7}{2} = 1.5\)

For \(O_2^{2-} = \cfrac{10-8}{2} = 1\)

Thus, the order is: \(O_2^{2-} < O_2^- < O_2 < O_2^+\)
